instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.P5VS4RS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS4RS3_PGOOD? P5VS4RS3_PGOOD is a signal that confirms the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail is working properly. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.P1V8S3_PGOOD: What is P1V8S3_PGOOD? P1V8S3_PGOOD is a signal that denotes that the PP1V8_S3 power rail is working..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.1A after a liquid damage
threads.message:
Had short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> replaced <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>
Now have G3H up, but stuck at 0.1A

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

Pgood signals don't seem to be up around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, apart than
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> - 3.3v


<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is providing PGOOD2 but not PGOOD1 i.e. <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

Detected heat signatures around 
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> - replaced still same
<CHIP>U3900</CHIP>- reflowed as there were liquid signs around it
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> - reflowed, still same

any suggestions where else to look,.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.1A after a liquid damage
threads.message: If board stays on, post voltage at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.1A after a liquid damage
threads.message:
Thanks for the response [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]

pin3: 0.015V
pin7: 0.015V

Only voltages I am getting on this gate is pin8 and 2 <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL>

On the other side, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> side of <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> is low, while  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> is high. I wonder if some of the other lines are pulling it down?

When unsoldered in this order:
<RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR> - <SIGNAL>P1V8S3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0.7V
<RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR> - P5VS3RS3 - 0.7V
<RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR> - P1V05S0 - 0.9V
<RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> - When I removed this one too and no other _PGOOD resistors left apart than <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>,  I have jumping 3.3V on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on 5 sec low / 1 sec high interval.

Is that expected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.1A after a liquid damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.1A after a liquid damage
threads.message:
Before I solder _PGOOD resistors back it was 0V
When I resolder them back still 0V and seems like I have lost 0.1A power draw and the orange light on the charge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.1A after a liquid damage
threads.message:
So no voltage on other coils now?

<RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> corresponds to power good of DDR voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 0.1A after a liquid damage
threads.message:
Yeah, there is quite of a corrosion trace around one of the memory chip legs. Perhaps damaged underneath causing the issue. 
Perhaps its time to pull the trigger on this one. 

Thank you again for all the support
